PREFACE
The following interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's
collection of oral testimonies. Rights to the interview are held by the United States Holocaust
Memorial Museum.
The reader should bear in mind that this is a verbatim transcript of spoken, rather than
written prose. This transcript has been neither checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy, and
therefore, it is possible that there are errors. As a result, nothing should be quoted or used from
this transcript without first checking it against the taped interview.
Transcribed by Nichole Miller, National Court Reporters Association.

MATILDA "JUNE" BAKKER
October 7, 2013

segments.question: This is a United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mrs.  Matilda Bakker, who goes by the name of "June Bakker," on October 7th, 2013, in  Catonsville, Maryland. Thank you very much, Ms. Bakker, for agreeing to speak with us  today. I'm going to start this interview at the very beginning. As I explained a little bit  earlier, we conduct interviews with people about their entire life story. So I'm going to  start at the beginning by asking you your name at birth, your date of birth, and where you  were born.
Could you tell me--
segments.answer: Well, I was born in 1920 in The Hague in the Netherlands.

segments.question: In the capital of the Netherlands?  UNIDENTIFIED MALE SPEAKER: No.

data: It isn't?  UNIDENTIFIED MALE SPEAKER: No. Amsterdam is the capital, but the government  is in The Hague.

Oh, that's why I was under a misimpression.  UNIDENTIFIED MALE SPEAKER: It's kind of mixed up. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. Rekia, Matilda Rekia (ph)?
Okay. What were your father and your mother's names?
segments.answer: Oh, my father's name was Marius.

segments.question: Marius?
Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Marius, Marius Rekia (ph), and my mother's name was Gertrude Christina.

-- if we Anglicized it?

segments.question: Aha. Was your father -- was your father often at home? Often on business? Did he --  was he a distant person, or was it somebody you were very close to?
I mean, well, sometimes when people were in high positions in companies, the family  didn't see them much because they were so busy.
He was every day. Okay. Did he come home for lunch, for example?
Okay. Tell me a little bit about his personality, your father's personality.

During the war, when I was in the resistance, sometimes Nazis would come to the  door and find out things. And my mother, she would -- she would go to bed when  something like that was happening, because that happens during the war, people would --  the Nazis would go --  UNIDENTIFIED MALE SPEAKER: Raids.
Huh?

segments.answer: And my mother -- because my mother said, "God says that you shall never lie, and I  cannot lie. So then I have to tell them what I know about you." And then --but she went  to bed. She -- she acted like she was asleep or sick or whatever. And my father told the  Nazis that I was in Germany working for them.

segments.question: So your father had no problem with that kind of twisting of the truth?
segments.answer: No, he did not have any problem with it. But she disappeared because she said, "God  says you may not lie."

segments.question: Okay. So --
segments.answer: So that's how idiotic it was.

data: When you moved to the United States, your parents --
Five years later, my parents came to visit us, and they stayed with us for six months.  UNIDENTIFIED MALE SPEAKER: Yeah.

And my father brought -- he said, "We went through your office, through your stuff  that you left." And then -- because I was going to work here for one year and go back.
